awd_abstract_narration:
Frozen Planet II, a new television series, will introduce viewers to the extraordinary beauty and critical importance of our frozen planet.  Due to be broadcast in the UK in late 2021 and the US in early 2022, it will air ten years after the original Frozen Planet series, giving a critically-timed insight into the fastest-changing part of our planet. While connecting with the greatest global audience possible, it will bring to the fore the challenges these frozen worlds face and the global consequences that could arise from their demise. Building on the hallmarks of the original series -- spectacular cinematography, compelling storytelling, scientific accuracy and never-before-seen animal behavior -- Frozen Planet II is intent on advancing knowledge and understanding of the natural world by showcasing environmental change and its consequences on wildlife. This is woven into the narrative core of the series, with a final episode devoted entirely to the future of these worlds. Complementing the broadcasts, the project will develop online educational materials and a robust social media campaign.
 
This award is for logistic support only for filming marine life and landscapes with NSF-supported research programs at McMurdo and Palmer Stations in Antarctica. In the decade since the original Frozen Planet was produced, there have been considerable advances in three key aspects of wildlife film-making: camera and sensor technology, exploration techniques and storytelling itself. Stories that would have been impossible to tell ten years ago are now achievable - from filming krill bioluminescing by using new low-light camera systems, to capturing extraordinary underwater encounters through the use of rebreather diving technology. Frozen Planet II's remit is to both inform and entertain a global audience with stories about the wonders of Antarctica and the creatures that live there, and show viewers parts of the continent and behaviors that they have not seen before. This series will be filmed predominantly in 8K and delivered for broadcast in 4K. The aim is to show dramatic scenes of animal behavior, highlighting the diversity of life in this the most hostile place on Earth; to show the wealth of landscapes both on the continent and in the ocean that surrounds it; and, through featuring scientists at work in Antarctica to reveal the changes already occurring and the challenges ahead, some of which are only just beginning to be understood. This project is supported by the NSF Office of Polar Programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Frozen Planet II

NB: The series Frozen Planet 2 is due for transmission in 2022. As such, the broader impacts in relation to the educational outreach of the series with regards to communicating science, nature and the conservation of our natural world to the widest possible audience cannot be quantified in this report. 

 

The outcomes of the project entitled Frozen Planet II (10/15/2019 - 03/31/2020) with regard to the intellectual merit and the forecast broader impacts are, to date, regarded as extremely positive. The initial broad design of activities to be undertaken outlined 10 unique stories to be filmed on the continent of Antarctica, which together would fulfil the anticipated outcomes of the project:

 

  • To feature dramatic scenes of animal behavior to highlight the diversity of life in Antarctica. 
  • To share extraordinary visual perspectives not seen before, thus showcasing the wealth of landscapes both on the continent and in the ocean that surrounds it. 
  • To feature scientists on screen; at work in some of the most extreme conditions on the planet, to highlight the changes already occurring and the challenges ahead for Antarctica - some of which we are only beginning to understand.

 

All of the anticipated outcomes are currently on track to be achieved. I suggest: Three stories were cancelled ahead of the field season due to logistical reasons. The remaining 7 stories were filmed successfully thanks to the infallible support of NSF personnel and the work of the award winning production teams and camera operators. Every project participant possesses a broad and unique array of expertise (e.g. filming seals under pack ice using Rebreather diving technology; managing field camps in the remote Dry Valleys); the likes of which are necessary to operate in Antarctica and to deliver the exclusive insights into the natural world, which the BBC prides itself on. 

 

Due to the transmission of the series postdating the publication of this report, it is not possible to give specific details of the project’s filming outcomes. These will be available to a global audience in 2022. The following detail regarding 3 of the key successes can be supplied (not an exhaustive list: 

 

  • Achieving groundbreaking insights into Weddell seal interactions under ice thanks to the use of Rebreather technology. Many of these interactions, such as those between a mother and pup, are believed to be the best observations available to science. Thus, as well as delivering scenes of dramatic animal behavior, the footage will also aid the work of NSF scientists.  
  • Filming unique footage of the Victoria Valley Sand Dunes and the Onyx River in Antarctica’s Dry Valleys. For the first time ever, the first flow of the Onyx River has been documented, while an Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) has captured aerial imagery of the spectacular dune formations. Extraordinary footage of katabatic winds captured by the helicopter team will allow the BBC to tell the complete story of how these spectacular valleys and their ventifacts were formed.
  • Capturing extraordinary footage of Type C Killer whales spy hopping within Weddell seal holes. This was captured from all angles using a UAV, a GSS mounted to a helicopter, a long lens 8K camera and a pole-camera. The latter allows a unique view into the underwater habitat. The number of Killer whales witnessed using seal holes is believed to have never been seen by a BBC audience and will be provided to NSF scientists to assist their research. 

 

With regard to intellectual merit, it was intended this project would connect with the greatest global audience possible, and bring to the fore the conservation and climate change challenges Antarctica is currently facing – and the worldwide consequences that could arise. Presently, the footage acquired across the duration of the award period is under editorial review by a team of prodigious and acclimated natural history documentary producers and editors. Furthermore, scientific consultants are in the process of fact-checking the scripts accompanying the footage. With all of the above in mind, to date the project’s intention with regard to intellectual merit is well on track to succeed.    

 

With regard to the broader impact of the project: The BBC’s global audience is at the heart of everything the BBC does. The BBC is confident the footage acquired will be of global significance, and it is intended to use such impact to promote STEM research on Earth’s frozen worlds on a huge scale. This confidence is based in part due to the present and ongoing expert review of the footage mentioned above; a sizeable global audience; an ability to reach traditionally underserved demographics globally; and comparison to previous BBC successes with regards to educational assets and societal impacts, for example the impact on the recent production Blue Planet II on driving interest in marine biology and oceanography. 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/15/2020
Modified by: Orla Doherty
